There have been numerous '''domestic responses to the [[2011 Egyptian protests]]'''. Opposition parties, activists and religious bodies (except for Christian authorities that called for staying away from the protests, though individuals have taken part) have been staunchly demanding [[President of Egypt|Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s resignation amidst media censorship. Global equity and commodity financial markets responded to the tumultuous events negatively due to concern for instability.
â
{{Politics of Egypt}}
  â
There have been numerous '''domestic responses to the [[2011 Egyptian protests]]'''. Opposition parties, activists and religious bodies (except for Christian authorities that called for staying away from the protests, though individuals have taken part) have been staunchly demanding [[President of Egypt|Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s resignation amidst media censorship. Global equity and commodity financial markets responded to the tumultous events negatively due to concern for instability.
 
Mubarak has made some initial changes to quell dissent, including dissolving his government, and appointing military figure and former head of Egypt's intelligence service [[Omar Suleiman]] as Vice-President. Mubarak asked aviation minister and former chief of Egypt's Air Force, Ahmed Shafiq, to form a new government. Opposition to the Mubarak regime has coalesced around [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], with all major opposition groups supporting his role as a negotiator for some form of transitional unity government.<ref>{{Registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite news|author=Shadid, Anthony; Kirpatrick, David D. |title=Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/31/world/middleeast/31-egypt.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref>
Mubarak has made some initial changes to quell dissent, including dissolving his government, and appointing military figure and former head of Egypt's intelligence service [[Omar Suleiman]] as Vice-President. Mubarak asked aviation minister and former chief of Egypt's Air Force, Ahmed Shafiq, to form a new government. Opposition to the Mubarak regime has coalesced around [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], with all major opposition groups supporting his role as a negotiator for some form of transitional unity government.<ref>{{Registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite news|author=Shadid, Anthony; Kirpatrick, David D. |title=Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/31/world/middleeast/31-egypt.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref>
==Government==
==Government==
  +
{{Politics of Egypt}}
The head of the [[Shura Council|Egyptian Shura Council]]'s Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, and also a part of the ruling party, said he does not believe the protests have ended yet.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs better source}}Breaking News. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. 29 January 2011. ~2:00</ref>
The head of the [[Shura Council|Egyptian Shura Council]]'s Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, and also a part of the ruling party, said he does not believe the protests have ended yet.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs better source}}Breaking News. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. 29 January 2011. ~2:00</ref>

Opposition and civil society activists have called for changes to a number of legal and constitutional provisions which affect elections. Specifically they call for:
Opposition and civil society activists have called for changes to a number of legal and constitutional provisions which affect elections. Specifically they call for:
*Amendment of Article 76 of the Constitution to make it easier for party and independent candidates to get on the presidential ballot.
*Amendment of Article 76 of the Constitution to make it easier for party and independent candidates to get on the presidential ballot.
Line 244: Line 245:
===Muslim Brotherhood===
===Muslim Brotherhood===
  +
[[File:Leave in several languages.png|150px|thumb|Leave in several languages.]]
In response to the 25 January events, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said: "Egypt is undergoing important events where the Egyptian people started a movement in Cairo and other cities in the country expressing their anger and denouncing the practices and violations by the system." Following Mubarak's speech,{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=which speech?}} the brotherhood issued a statement reiterating demands for Mubarak's resignation and saying it was time for the military to intervene.<ref>{{dead link|date=January 2011|reason=ARCHIVE version is dead link. webcitation.org fails on various platforms (if it works at all)}}{{cite web | author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 | title=Live: Egypt Unrest | accessdate=29 January 2011 | date=28 January 2011 | work=[[BBC News]] | archivedate=29 January 2011 | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w5dpTRTE | quote=Mubarak must step down. It is time for the military to intervene and save the country.}}{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=who is speaking? an editorial in the media? someone is quoted?}}</ref> The brotherhood also said it would not be nominating a new president.
In response to the 25 January events, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said: "Egypt is undergoing important events where the Egyptian people started a movement in Cairo and other cities in the country expressing their anger and denouncing the practices and violations by the system." Following Mubarak's speech,{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=which speech?}} the brotherhood issued a statement reiterating demands for Mubarak's resignation and saying it was time for the military to intervene.<ref>{{dead link|date=January 2011|reason=ARCHIVE version is dead link. webcitation.org fails on various platforms (if it works at all)}}{{cite web | author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 | title=Live: Egypt Unrest | accessdate=29 January 2011 | date=28 January 2011 | work=[[BBC News]] | archivedate=29 January 2011 | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w5dpTRTE | quote=Mubarak must step down. It is time for the military to intervene and save the country.}}{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=who is speaking? an editorial in the media? someone is quoted?}}</ref> The brotherhood also said it would not be nominating a new president.
